awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an X-Ray Fluorescence (XRF) Vacuum Spectrometer
awd_abstract_narration:
MRI: Acquisition of an X-Ray Fluorescence (XRF) Vacuum Spectrometer at Franklin & Marshall College

This grant supports the acquisition of a new, state-of-the-art X-ray fluorescence (XRF) vacuum spectrometer at Franklin & Marshall College. X-ray fluorescence (XRF) is an analytical technique that produces a chemical analysis of solid materials. The new XRF will be used to conduct basic geological and chemistry research and undergraduate student training in classes and projects in these subject areas. Suitably trained undergraduates at institutions with XRF instruments can perform accurate and precise chemical analyses of rocks and other solid materials. Undergraduate classes in geology, inorganic chemistry, materials science, and undergraduate research projects, guided by a faculty member, will benefit from incorporating the new XRF in the curriculum.

This grant supports the acquisition of a new, state-of-the-art X-ray fluorescence (XRF) vacuum spectrometer at Franklin & Marshall College. XRF instruments measure the major and trace element geochemistry of solid materials, including rocks, to provide the basis for understanding provenance, processes of formation in geological applications and material composition and purity in material science and chemistry applications. The new XRF instrument contains a 4 kW rhodium x-ray tube, which has been designed to conquer the sublimation of tungsten from the cathode to the region around the radiation exit window, thus providing virtually constant output over the entire tube life, coupled with a modern software package that is interfaced with all new electrical XRF components. Continued collaborative work with NASA, Canadian Space Agency, University of Alberta, Kansas State University, University of Winnipeg, University of Addis Ababa and others, will benefit from the much-improved data quality provided by this instrument. In addition to the research applications, the new XRF will be used as a teaching tool in undergraduate classes in geology and chemistry. Geology Department seniors will have access to the instrument for their senior theses on rock samples they collect during their summer field work between junior and senior year. In addition, students from other classes in geology and chemistry will complete independent research projects utilizing the XRF instrument.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Award #182731 to Franklin and Marshall College funded the purchase of a x-ray fluorescence vacuum spectrometer equipped with a 4 kilowatt rhodium x-ray tube. This type of instrumentation has the capability of detecting most of the naturally occurring chemical elements on the Periodic Chart. With suitable calibration; that is, using a collection of rock and mineral powders of known chemical composition, thus permitting elemental concentrations in unknown samples to be determined. Physical and material scientists and engineers use quantitative chemical data to evaluate potential relationships between what a material is made of and its physical characteristics, like structural strength, melting temperature, ductility, and so forth.

In addition to improved, more comprehensive software, and more stable electronics, the x-ray tube has been dramatically changed for the better. The x-ray tube has been re-designed to prevent tungsten from the filament wire from sublimating onto the orifice where the tube radiation exits the tube on its way to bombard the sample. In all previous x-ray tube generations the tungsten sublimation issue led to a self-absorption process which produced a slow but steady decrease in  x-ray tube intensity from day #1. A mechanism to have the tungsten sublimate (a gas that forms a solid upon cooling never going through a liquid state) to a location in the tube other than the exit port for all radiation, means that the output radiation stays constant over the life of the tube; no more steadily declining radiation intensity as a function of time. This change makes the instrument calibration much more stable over time, making recalibration a much less frequent process. Beautiful! What an improvement. It makes the analytical data more precise over time, less variability is always a good thing.

 Undergraduate students who take courses in mineralogy and petrology at Franklin and Marshall College learn how to prepare minerals and rocks for chemical analysis using XRF technology. It is a great example of hands-on learning, essentially an apprenticeship education, learning by doing. In the petrology course each student chooses a rock that is used in the building / kitchen / bathroom industries from the Cold Spring Granite Company of Minnesota as her / his « pet rock » for the within course research project. First, they make a thin section for mineral identifcation purposes. Once they are familiar with the sample’s minerals and textures, they embark upon a series of 4 experiments to determine : 1) the total volatile content in their rock sample, 2) the major element chemistry (SiO2, Al2O3, MgO, Na2O, P2O5, Fe2O3, MnO, TiO2, CaO, and K2O), 3) the trace element chemistry (Rb, Sr, Y, Zr, Nb, Ba, Ni, Cr, V, Co, Cu, Zn, Ga, Sc, Pb, La, Ce, U, and Th., and 4) a titration technique to determine the Fe+2 in their rock. Assembling all the mineralogical and chemical data into a cogent report, interpreting it as best they can given their coursework and outside readings in petrology, handing in their final report and presenting their results to the entire class in a mini-symposium : welcome to petrology at Franklin and Marshall College.

  • Depicted is the sample loading deck of the Zetium XRF spectrometer. Fusion glass disks are picked up individually and loaded into a sample cup and moved into the loading port for introduction to the vacuum chamber. Analysis for high concentrion elements takes ~20 minutes. Those at the ppm level: 80.

  • This instrument is used to characterize the chemistry of solid materials. For geologists the solid materials will invariably be rocks and minerals. XRF instrumentation is an essential linkage between three fields of study: geology, chemistry, and materials science.
